Thanks for sharing. Relapse rates are high and they‚Äôre common in 2 to 5 year windows, you‚Äôre not alone. Sorry to hear you‚Äôre still battling a depressive episode, 3 years is awful, hope things turn around for you soon.

Sounds like it, yes. I also have season symptoms, each time I‚Äôve been manic happened during spring/summer. Research shows light exposure can aggravate symptoms as it disrupts circadian rhythms. A common trigger for mania.

Me too. There seems to be some continuity in how they‚Äôre symptoms present as if they became resistant to their medication all of a sudden. Good news, most were able to halt a severe manic episode by changing dosage or meds as soon as they realized symptoms were happening

Happy to hear ur doing better. I came across 2 research journals that cite a 65%-73% relapse rate every 2-5 years for people w/ type 1 (even higher for those who also experience psychosis). But there are lucky ppl who will go episode free 4 life after finding the right treatment

I‚Äôm bipolar, lost my 15+ yr job after a manic episode in July (I didn‚Äôt know I was bipolar at the time). I‚Äôm just now feeling ok with finding a new job. My doctor is prepared to make ‚Äúreasonable accommodations‚Äù request for my disability to help foster a healthier work environment

Weight gain is the worst side effect. Have u heard of Metformin? It‚Äôs a diabetes med often prescribed for bipolar to combat weight gain. It helps regulate blood sugar & stop metabolic syndrome (which causes the weight gain from taking antipsychotics). I‚Äôm on it, it‚Äôs been helpful
#bipolardisorder and metabolic syndrome. Bipolar medications are also known to cause metabolic syndrome, leading to significant (and unwanted) weight gain. https://t.co/lSyoUsfiFB

Lithium, Ziprasidone, Lamotrogine, Metformin & Ambien. Took a year to find the right combo for me and have been stable since September. Tried 19 different ones before and dealt with so many awful side effects, grateful to be where I‚Äôm at now.
